comments.text:
+The Rageaholic DISCLAIMER: Don't hate me. I'm disagreeing with you, not 
insulting your mother. I actually like your style and reviews.

I have to disagree with the OP that this is a terrible review, but I 
definitely disagree with you that the game is a step backwards. For all of 
it's faults (and there's a lot more than you mentioned, some far less 
trivial), the core gameplay is still really fantastic. 

Actual problems with the game that you didn't bring up:
1) plateauing of difficulty. Perfectionist is an ass-pain for the intro 
level and the level after that. Then it's mildly challenging, then it's 
trivial for the rest of the game. The dev's could have done a lot better 
job of keeping the challenge up to speed as the game progressed.
2) ass-backwards controls. In a stealth game, movement is key (crazy, 
right?). It's incredibly frustrating when sam fisher, the best spy in the 
world, decides to open a door instead of vaulting through a window. You 
have to have incredible luck or incredible skill to get the right button at 
the right time.
3) the dev's clearly want you to ghost. I get that it's a spy game, but in 
nearly every level playing assault is as hard (if not harder) than playing 
as a ghost, at least on perfectionist.
4) lack of gun diversity. Weapons go from bad to good. beginner pistol is 
shit, last pistol is great. No variety, just good to bad. Seems lazy.
4) health regen in perfectionist. Would have been so much better if health 
didn't regenerate. Then there would be an actual challenge.


positives: on perfectionist, there is a sense of accomplishment, especially 
on side missions. Some of them (due to bad design perhaps) are nigh 
impossible to beat (charlie's 4E mission: Swiss embassy), and getting it 
right feels great. 

I really think despite it's flaws, the game accomplished what it sets out 
to do and provides the gamer with an enjoyable experience.

captions.text:
'This game is a work of fiction,' says Ubisoft,
at the outset of this espionage opus. 'Any

similarity to real or historical events is
coincidental.' Gee, thanks for the disclaimer,

slick! Might have confused it with all those
geriatric superspies doing ninja flips off

walls in real life! (Sure, I used that joke
on Twitter, but it's my joke and fuck you,

I'll do what I want!)
Now, before we progress to the actual viscera

of the review, allow me to feed the starving
pachyderm affixed to the center of the living

room.
The voice.

It sucks, people. It sucks exceptionally hard,
in fact.

Replacing Michael Ironside with a 10-year-old
we've never heard of from a TV show we've

never watched... is like Motörhead replacing
Lemmy with Robin fucking Thicke. Or like...

I dunno... replacing Stephen Russel as Garrett
in the Thief series with some... bargain-basement

Montréal local with an accent an inch thicker
than the lead designer's skull and shouting

down any and all criticism of his subpar,
somnolent performance thereafter, but now

I'm just talkin' crazy.
Eric Johnson's vocal performance doesn't suck

because he isn't Michael Ironside. It sucks
because it's lifeless, generic, and utterly

devoid of subtext or dramatic nuance. Which
comes into particularly sharp focus when the

player engages in phone conversations with
Sam's daughter, Sarah... who at this point,

sounds about 5 years older than he does!
But it also isn't entirely the new actor's

fault.
Michael Ironside was done with Splinter Cell.

Full stop.
And after enduring the cacophony of Fox Network

primetime drama cliché that comprised the
plot of Splinter Cell: Conviction, what rational

human being could possibly blame him?! To
hear him tell it, he was collecting a paycheck

and faxing in his performance as early as
Chaos Theory. Leaving the project is a prerogative

he's more than earned, but this kid?!
He ain't Sam Fisher. He never will be Sam

Fisher. Why hamfist his crewcut-bedecked ass
into a role he will never be accepted in?

The co-op campaigns featured in the last four
fucking games have illustrated that Sam Fisher

is far from the only operative with his particular
skill set: Let a new hero emerge! Why milk

poor Sam like the only goat on the dairy farm!?
Roll up your sleeves, dust off your mottled

tome of spy film tropes... and motherfucking
create!!!

The first thing you will notice in Blacklist
is Lens flare!

Lens flare URRRRRRRRRRRVERYwhere!
A car's headlights, an enemy's headset, Sam

Fisher's hairline... if it can even remotely
be construed as a light source... then it

is wreathed in a linear flare the likes of
which invariably obscure no less than a fifth

of the fucking screen!
Because reasons!

As the absolute first order of business, it
is your right, nay... your duty as a cognizant,

fully-evolved homo sapien life form... to
hit the 'select' button... head it on over

to the options menu... and turn tutorial messages
the fuck off! I'm all for being inclusive,

but when I'm perpetually dodging insightful
chestnuts like "When you're hidden... bad

guys can't see you"... DIE... THE FUCK...
TODAY, UBISOFT!

And on the subject of 'bad guys': Increased
enemy variety - after Conviction's torpid

typhoon of interchangeable rent-a-cops - is
a very welcome development. Unfortunately,

this also left the door open for some aspiring
neurosurgeon at Ubisoft to bring canine enemies

back into the fold... with every last one
of the design problems they invariably generate

in tow!
Ubisoft: I have watched my dog stand mystified

before a mirror, utterly convinced the identical
dog in the mirror in front of him... is all

that's preventing him from entering "the other
hallway". I've seen him completely disregard

the mailman, yet erupt into barking fits over
a howling bloodhound on Animal Planet. Dogs

can hear shit. Dogs can see shit. Given the
time and opportunity, they can even eat shit.

They can neither hear nor smell shit... from
an adjacent fucking land mass.

You're not thinking of a dog.
You're thinking of Daredevil.

As long as I've had to wait for a proper Daredevil
video game... I think we'd all still prefer

it if he didn't debut with four legs, snipped
off balls, and a propensity for fucking my

calf.
Canine precognition aside, in many ways, the

ingredients for a 5-star stealth-'em-up are
present and accounted for: With the return

of franchise and genre hallmarks such as the
hiding of bodies, sprawling, multifacted maps,

and (wonder of wonders) even full-on fucking
ghosting. In practice, however, each one of

these elements has been shorn to a dull fucking
nub in a mortifying process that results in

the complete removal of any and all of its
original character and subtlety.

Sure, they brought back loadout customization
- even enhanced it by ripping more than a

few frayed pages from the Gospel According
to Alpha Protocol - but when you really analyze

the little details in how these systems function,
it becomes nakedly apparent that Ubisoft is

still living into the idea of having the remotest
fucking inkling of a clue. Little details

like... how you can press against a wall for
cover... but can no longer stand up after

doing so. How you can take human shields,
but can't initiate interrogations without

it being part of some ingratiating, pre-scripted
event.

"I'm not making the same mistakes again."
"No. You're making... you're making all new

ones."
In older Splinter Cell titles (See also: The

ones that actually fucking sold) every element
of play seemed devoted to the unifying principle

that it was the player - not Sam Fisher himself
- who was the star of the game. In Conviction,

the Montréal studio wrested the controller
from the player's hands and proceeded to drunkenly

teabag the player for seven hours, but in
Blacklist...?

They reluctantly began to sober up, surrendering
a fractional measure of control as a gift

and a peace offering.
What you learn over the course of Urgent Walking:

The Video Game...
"The Engineers left a breadcrumb trail of

false information."
"To send us running into a minefield."

"Let's hope the DEVGRU teams found something."
"You're selling out that bill, Josh!"

"Donna!"
"There's a situation on the Treaty."

"A situation?"
"...on the Treaty."

"A Treaty situation."
"I dated a hooker."

"You'll sense important things are happening
because there's lots of urgent walking and

political jargon. And you'll feel smarter
having watched that than Full House reruns,

that's for sure."
...is that you should have asked for the fucking

receipt.
And lamentably, the aforementioned gameplay

overhaul comes at the expense of arguably
the single most crucial attribute of any successful

video game, and that, my friend, is a little
ditty by the name of 'consistency'.

When I push 'B', Mega Man shoots a white ball
out of his fuckin' arm cannon.

When I push 'L2', Solid Snake cycles through
his item inventory.

To put a finer point on it, if the game devotes
entire swaths of time to hammering home the

concept that depressing the circle button
causes Sam to dismount from a ledge... then,

by God, pushing circle had better disengage
my ass from the goddamn ledge!

'Oh no, but you see, Sam's too far from the
ground, here. He can only drop from that height

if he's crushing a man's skull in the process.'
No. No. No... You condescending simp.

If circle is what makes me drop... then let
me fucking drop! If it's too far from the

ground, I'll probably acquire a fuckin' clue
around the time my ankles simultaneously compound

fracture! Welcome to basic problem solving,
assface. Quit leading me around by my earlobes

like a fucking seven-year-old!
The level design vacillates manically between

marginally impressive and inspired... to among
the worst I've ever had the displeasure of

experiencing. Forays into Iraq and Afghanistan
are compelling, but then the Paraguay Villa

shambles through the doorway in an inebriated
stupor, reeking of syphilitic slatch and shame.

As if it were slapped haphazardly together
as a refresher course in how to do absolutely

everything wrong!
And on that subject, may I just say that--

UBISOFT! CHECKPOINTS DO NOT FUCKING WORK IN
STEALTH GAMES! EVER!

"EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE--"
Literally, the only thing wrong with Pandora

Tomorrow is its checkpoint-based save system!
A problem your own studio acknowledged by

allowing the player to save anywhere in Chaos
Theory, Double Agent, and the HD re-release

of the first two games! Stop un-learning from
your own past mistakes!

Can you imagine if car manufacturers operated
by Ubisoft logic? 'Yeah, sure, we could slap

a fuel-efficient hybrid V-6 on this puppy...
but I think I'd rather the new Mazeratti ran

on fucking coal power?!' Checkpoints? Arbitrary
item limits? Not to sound like your A.A. sponsor,

but I thought we were past this shit?!
Given the gameplay overhaul and renewed focus

on stealth, it is now abundantly clear that
Ubisoft Montréal is fully aware of the mistakes

they made with Conviction... yet, bafflingly,
decided to make most of them all over again!

Ergo, you leave me little choice but to dub
thee: Splinter Cell: Backslide!

I'm RazörFist.
God - fucking - speed!
